DOC.HEAD: New Orleans D.A., Actor Plead Innocent in Gambling Case
DOC.TEXT: District Attorney Harry Connick and actor Paul Burke pleaded innocent Thursday to charges that they schemed to help an arrested bookie continue a gambling operation. The two were among nine people indicted Dec. 15. Magistrate Louis Moore Jr. set bond at $10,000 apiece for Connick, Burke and four others, and at $20,000 apiece for convicted bookmaker Walton Aucoin, 49, and Steven Bertolino, 57, accused of taking part in the bookmaking operation. All were allowed to sign for their bonds without putting up cash. ``I did nothing wrong. ... The allegations are pure D baloney,'' said Connick, who gained notoriety this year with a continuing attempt to revive Louisiana's anti-abortion laws. He could get up to 25 years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted on the charges against him. The indictment accuses Connick of giving Aucoin gambling records seized when Aucoin was arrested in December 1988. Connick has said it was proper to give Aucoin records needed for his defense. A grand jury said the records were provided to help Aucoin continue collecting and paying gambling debts. Connick has repeatedly said the indictment is the result of a personal vendetta by U.S. Attorney John Volz, who began the federal investigation but later turned it over to the U.S. Justice Department in Washington. Also charged in the case are Wilson P. Abraham, 70, a New Orleans real estate developer who pleaded innocent Wednesday, William G. Condon, 34; Iris Ethridge, 30; Aucoin's daughter, Darleen Aucoin Toca, 27; and Patrick Fanning, a defense lawyer who was once an assistant district attorney and an assistant U.S. attorney. Aucoin, Bertolino, Condon, Ms. Ethridge and Ms. Toca were charged with owning and conducting a New Orleans-based illegal interstate gambling operation that allegedly netted as much as $2,000 a day. Fanning, Abraham and Burke were charged with aiding the operation by helping Connick cook up an excuse for returning the records Aucoin needed to keep it going. The excuse was, according to the indictment, that Aucoin needed the records to pay his federal gambling stamp taxes. Burke was once a star of television's ``The Naked City'' and appeared in ``The Valley of the Dolls'' and other movies. He is a New Orleans native now living in Palm Springs, Calif., according to the indictment. Connick wants to act as his own co-counsel along with defense lawyer Bill Wessels, Wessels told the court. The trial was tenatively set for March 1.
